item.title: School’s Out, Indefinitely, in West Bank as a Teachers Strike Gains Momentum
item.description: A dispute that began with demands for a pay raise has turned into a broad challenge to the Palestinian Authority.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and RAMI NAZZAL
item.media:description: Palestinian teachers protested last month in Hebron, West Bank.

item.title: Unease After Donald Trump Depicts Tokyo as an Economic Rival
item.description: In an attack reminiscent of another era, Donald J. Trump has chastised Japan as a country where “we are getting absolutely crushed on trade.”
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Donald Trump in 1987 at his home in Greenwich, Conn.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Kill 150 Shabab Fighters in Somalia, Officials Say
item.description: The strikes hit a camp where officials said fighters with the Shabab militant group were preparing an attack against American troops and their allies.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Playing Pass the Parcel With Fukushima
item.description: Keeping radioactive waste in motion between provisional storage sites isn't a policy; it's an elaborate dodge.
item.dc:creator: PETER WYNN KIRBY

item.title: Insider Podcasts: Former Jerusalem Bureau Chief Answers Readers’ Questions
item.description: The deputy international editor, Jodi Rudoren answers reader-submitted questions about her work and life as Jerusalem bureau chief
item.dc:creator: SUSAN LEHMAN
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times

item.title: Mexico’s Leader Likens Donald Trump’s Tone to Hitler and Mussolini’s
item.description: President Enrique Peña Nieto also said that his country would not pay for Mr. Trump’s proposed wall along the border with the United States.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico in Mexico City in January.

item.title: Thanat Khoman, Thai Statesman and Co-Founder of Asian Alliance, Dies at 101
item.description: Mr. Thanat helped the United States gain military bases in Thailand during the Vietnam War and helped start the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.media:credit: Robert Knudsen/White House, via John F. Kennedy Presidential Library
item.media:description: Thanat Khoman, the foreign minister of Thailand, met with President John F. Kennedy in the Oval Office in 1961.

item.title: Egyptian Aviation Student Who Made Trump Threat Is Leaving U.S.
item.description: Emadeldin Elsayed’s comments on Donald J. Trump’s idea to bar Muslims from the United States stirred debate about what is a threat or “mouthing off.”
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Emadeldin Elsayed, an Egyptian aviation student living in Los Angeles. This undated photo was provided by his brother Ohoud Ali Mohamed Nasr El Sayed.

item.title: Venezuela Opens Investigation Into Possible Killing of Miners
item.description: Family members of 28 missing miners have said that their relatives were murdered in a dispute over a gold claim.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Embargo Lifted, Iranian Oil Reaches Europe
item.description: A Spanish refinery received Iran’s first shipment of oil for Europe since the 2012 embargo was officially lifted in January.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: The tanker Monte Toledo delivered a shipment of Iranian oil to the refinery of Compañía Española de Petróleos, in Algeciras, a southern Spanish port near Gibraltar, on Sunday.

item.title: European Union Plan to Slow Flow of Refugees Stalls as Turkey Makes Demands
item.description: Turkish leaders asked for more money to deal with the millions of Syrian refugees and sought progress on their effort to join the European Union.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Migrants at the Greek-Macedonian border near the Greek village of Idomeni on Monday.

item.title: Ortega vs. the Contras: Nicaragua Endures an ’80s Revival
item.description: Violent opposition from small groups of rebels reflects broader anger brewing against President Daniel Ortega as he has consolidated his power.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers standing before President Daniel Ortega in August during an event in Managua celebrating the Nicaraguan Air Force.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Kill 150 Shabab Fighters in Somalia, Officials Say
item.description: The strikes hit a camp where officials said fighters with the Shabab militant group were preparing an attack against American troops and their allies.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Shabab Claim Responsibility for Blast at Somali Airport
item.description: A bomb in a laptop computer went off at a security checkpoint at the airport in Beletwein in central Somalia, wounding at least six people, officials said.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Letter From Europe: If Britain Leaves E.U., Some Fear France Would Stop Blocking Migrants at Calais
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron said France might abandon a 13-year-old treaty that moved immigration controls to the French side of the English Channel.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: Migrants in the camp known as the Jungle, near the port city of Calais in northern France.

item.title: Clash at Tunisian Military Barracks Near Libya Kills Dozens
item.description: The assault comes at a time of growing concern that the war in Libya, where the Islamic State has aggressively expanded, is spilling over.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: FARAH SAMTI and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Ringleader of British Jewelry Theft Is in Failing Health, Lawyer Says
item.description: Brian Reader, 77, who had been hospitalized after suffering a stroke in prison, was described as a “very sick and old man” at a sentencing hearing.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Brian Reader, 77, the architect of a burglary in London. “It may still be that he does not have many months to live,” said his lawyer, James Scobie.

item.title: Iran’s President Flouts News Media Blackout Against a Predecessor
item.description: Under a ban by judiciary officials, no Iranian outlet of any sort is permitted to mention Mohammad Khatami’s name or show his photograph.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Iranian Presidency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran during a visit to Yazd on Monday.

item.title: Gaiole in Chianti Journal: Italy’s Famed Wine Region a War Zone, Invaded by Boars and Others
item.description: Efforts in Chianti to reduce an exploding population of wild boars and deer, which devour grapes and the vines’ tender sprouts, are creating issues of their own.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wild boar going into the forest at dusk to forage for food in Chianti, Italy.

item.title: Sinosphere: Year After Detentions, Chinese Feminists Mark Setbacks and Progress
item.description: China’s first law against domestic violence took effect almost a year after five women were detained, causing an international uproar.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Li Tingting posing as Rosie the Riveter to mark the anniversary of her detention with four other feminists on the eve of International Women’s Day. The sign reads: “The full name of ‘Women’s Day’ is ‘International Women’s Labor Day!’ We don’t want your care and concern, we want rights!”
